qas.question: What are the set of genes which are thought to be crucial for the survival of an organism?
What does the definition of essential genes assume an absence of?
How many genes are essential for Escherichia coli?
What fraction of Escherichia coli's essential genes are orthologs?
How many essential genes does Saccharomyces cerevisiae have?

context: <a0_0>Essential genes<a0_0/> are the set of genes thought to be critical for an organism's survival. This definition assumes the abundant availability of all relevant nutrients and the absence of <a1_0>environmental stress<a1_0/>. Only a small portion of an organism's genes are essential. In bacteria, an estimated <a2_0>250–400<a2_0/> genes are essential for Escherichia coli and Bacillus subtilis, which is less than 10% of their genes. <a3_0>Half<a3_0/> of these genes are orthologs in both organisms and are largely involved in protein synthesis. In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae the number of essential genes is slightly higher, at <a4_0>1000 genes<a4_0/> (~20% of their genes). Although the number is more difficult to measure in higher eukaryotes, mice and humans are estimated to have around 2000 essential genes (~10% of their genes).
